subject: RE: [junit] RE: Isolation or Collaboration
msgSnippet: ... Exactly.  Even with a sane object, not all methods can be called at any time, and since your code has this restriction, it s not surprising to me that the
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Harald M. Muller

> > All objects should be in a "sane" state all the time. If not, then the
> > design could be improved to avoid this problem. The Pragmatic
> > Programmers call what you describe as "Programming by Coincidence".
> >
>
> "Sane state" does NOT mean that everything can be done to the
> object at every time. Cedric's "initialized" example is
> probably actually a design flaw, but for other states, it
> makes of course much sense to disallow certain operations: If
> a database connection is not open, you cannot execute a
> select; if a file has been deleted, it cannot be deleted a
> second time; a bill that has been cancelled cannot be
> invoiced; etc.etc.

Exactly. Even with a sane object, not all methods can be called at any
time, and since your code has this restriction, it's not surprising to me
that the tests should reflect that.

Instead of relying on a mock database, I'd rather use the real one on my
tests and if the connection fails, I want the testing framework to simply
*not* call any of my database tests and let me know they were not run.

> In many cases I saw and see, programmers/designers/architects
> seem to believe that the String class (where you can indeed
> execute every method sensibly at every time) is the
> paradigmatic example of a class. Nothing can be further from
> the truth: Many classes have an "interesting state diagram",
> where certain operations can only be invoked if certain
> conditions hold.

Interesting point.

> > > - A certain object can only be created if a previous object
> > has been created
> > > before.
> >
> > If so, then the previous object should be the only thing that can
> > create the new object!
>
> This is often contrary to design concepts with somewhat
> centralized responsibilities.

Agreed. Sometimes a method needs two objects to create a third one, and
this method doesn't belong to a class more than another.

> Still, on a more general level - e.g. when one talks about
> closely tied groups of classes (yes: they are there; not even
> one of the tutorials that explain JUnit pretends that
> litterally everything makes sense to be
> mocked) - the guidelines hinted at by JBR do make sense.

Yes. It's just that when you do testing, you very rapidly leave "unit
testing" (testing of one class) to do some other form of testing, and JUnit
starts being a strain when this happens in my experience because of these
deficiencies.
